    • ILSE: installation and simulated example

    ILSE: installation and simulated example

    Wei Liu

    2021-12-26

    ILSE.Simu.Rmd

    Install the ILSE

    This vignette provides an introduction to the R package ILSE, where the function ILSE implements the model ILSE, Linear Regression by Iterative Least Square Estimation (ILSE) When Covariates Include Missing Values. The package can be installed with the command from Github:

    library(remotes)

    remotes::install_github("feiyoung/ILSE")

    or install from CRAN

    install.packages("ILSE")

    The package can be loaded with the command:

    library("ILSE")
#> Loading required package: mvnmle
#> Loading required package: MASS
#> Warning: package 'MASS' was built under R version 4.0.4
#> ILSE :  Linear regression when covariates include missing values embedding the
#> correlation imformation bettwen covariates. Especially for block missing data,
#> it works well. ILSE conduct imputation and regression simultaneouly and iteratively.
#> 
#> Attaching package: 'ILSE'
#> The following object is masked from 'package:base':
#> 
#>     summary

    Fit linear model using simulated data

    First, we generate the data with homogeneous normal variables.

      n <- 100
  p <- 6
  X <- MASS::mvrnorm(n, rep(0, p), cor.mat(p, rho=0.5))
  beta0 <- rep(c(1,-1), times=3)
  Y <- -2+ X %*% beta0 + rnorm(n, sd=1)

    A special case: without missing values

    Then, we fit the linear regression model without missing values based on ILSE.

    ilse1 <- ilse(Y~X)
print(ilse1)
#> $beta
#>  intercept         X1         X2         X3         X4         X5         X6 
#> -1.9724071  0.8963815 -0.8172811  1.0873532 -1.2046588  1.0863035 -1.2066205 
#> 
#> $Bmat
#>            [,1]      [,2]       [,3]     [,4]      [,5]     [,6]     [,7]
#> iter0 -1.972407 0.8963815 -0.8172811 1.087353 -1.204659 1.086303 -1.20662
#> iter1 -1.972407 0.8963815 -0.8172811 1.087353 -1.204659 1.086303 -1.20662
#> 
#> $d.fn
#> [1] 0
#> 
#> $d.par
#> [1] 0
#> 
#> $iterations
#> [1] 1

    We can also create a (data.frame) object as input for ILSE.

    dat <- data.frame(Y=Y, X=X)
ilse1 <- ilse(Y~., data=dat)
print(ilse1)
#> $beta
#>  intercept        X.1        X.2        X.3        X.4        X.5        X.6 
#> -1.9724071  0.8963815 -0.8172811  1.0873532 -1.2046588  1.0863035 -1.2066205 
#> 
#> $Bmat
#>            [,1]      [,2]       [,3]     [,4]      [,5]     [,6]     [,7]
#> iter0 -1.972407 0.8963815 -0.8172811 1.087353 -1.204659 1.086303 -1.20662
#> iter1 -1.972407 0.8963815 -0.8172811 1.087353 -1.204659 1.086303 -1.20662
#> 
#> $d.fn
#> [1] 0
#> 
#> $d.par
#> [1] 0
#> 
#> $iterations
#> [1] 1
Coef(ilse1) # access the coefficients

    Check the significant variables by bootstratp.

    s1 <- summary(ilse1)
#> ===================Start bootstrapping================
#> [1] "==============running process: 10% ============="
#> [1] "==============running process: 20% ============="
#> [1] "==============running process: 30% ============="
#> [1] "==============running process: 40% ============="

#> [1] "==============running process: 70% ============="
#> [1] "==============running process: 80% ============="
#> [1] "==============running process: 90% ============="
#> [1] "==============running process: 100% ============="
#> ===================Finish bootstrapping================
s1

#> intercept -1.9724071  0.1000178 -19.720562 0.000000e+00

#> X.2       -0.8172811  0.1468166  -5.566680 2.596389e-08

#> X.6       -1.2066205  0.1082484 -11.146777 0.000000e+00

    Handle data with missing values

    First, we randomly remove some entries in X.

    mis_rate <- 0.3
set.seed(1)
na_id <- sample(1:(n*p), n*p*mis_rate)
Xmis <- X
Xmis[na_id] <- NA
ncomp <- sum(complete.cases(Xmis))
message("Number of complete cases is ", ncomp, '\n')
#> Number of complete cases is 9

    Second, we use lm to fit linear regression model based on complete cases, i.e., CC analysis. We can not detect any siginificant covariates.

    lm1 <- lm(Y~Xmis)
s_cc <- summary.lm(lm1)
s_cc
#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = Y ~ Xmis)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>       50       57       63       66       68       72       79       81 
#>  0.56091 -0.03238  0.53089  0.46470 -0.70006 -0.79444  0.07821 -0.73569 
#>       96 
#>  0.62787 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)
#> (Intercept)  -1.9702     0.9961  -1.978    0.187
#> Xmis1         0.4295     1.2206   0.352    0.759
#> Xmis2        -1.0268     2.4223  -0.424    0.713
#> Xmis3         1.3579     1.1141   1.219    0.347
#> Xmis4        -1.2781     0.7925  -1.613    0.248
#> Xmis5         0.3800     1.5139   0.251    0.825
#> Xmis6        -1.2203     1.1855  -1.029    0.412
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 1.199 on 2 degrees of freedom
#>   (91 observations deleted due to missingness)
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.9385, Adjusted R-squared:  0.7539 
#> F-statistic: 5.083 on 6 and 2 DF,  p-value: 0.1735

    Third, we use ILSE to fit the linear regression model based on all data.

    ilse2 <- ilse(Y~Xmis, data=NULL, infor_output=T)
#> iter:0d.fn:NAd.par:NA
#> par:-1.970.43-1.031.36-1.280.38-1.22
#> iter:1d.fn:0.104897962126958d.par:0.236193971235587
#> coefs:-1.630.81-0.60.89-0.930.35-1.14
#> iter:2d.fn:9.15712255961691e-05d.par:0.0347770463584336
#> coefs:-1.640.78-0.540.84-0.910.35-1.19
#> iter:3d.fn:0.000191688620118891d.par:0.00431484194314171
#> coefs:-1.650.78-0.540.83-0.910.35-1.19
#> iter:4d.fn:1.60836638105554e-06d.par:0.000264396781894253
#> coefs:-1.650.78-0.540.83-0.910.35-1.19
#> iter:5d.fn:1.95910806143854e-06d.par:3.89823884700356e-05
#> coefs:-1.650.78-0.540.83-0.910.35-1.19
#> iter:6d.fn:3.0025095220502e-07d.par:4.66612033027583e-06
#> coefs:-1.650.78-0.540.83-0.910.35-1.19
print(ilse2)
#> $beta
#>  intercept         X1         X2         X3         X4         X5         X6 
#> -1.6453080  0.7792716 -0.5383929  0.8287778 -0.9064403  0.3528486 -1.1913363 
#> 
#> $Bmat
#>            [,1]      [,2]       [,3]      [,4]       [,5]      [,6]      [,7]
#> iter0 -1.970238 0.4295143 -1.0267722 1.3579081 -1.2781154 0.3799882 -1.220275
#> iter1 -1.628854 0.8109200 -0.5992968 0.8925497 -0.9293833 0.3535375 -1.141259
#> iter2 -1.644628 0.7846078 -0.5449896 0.8359030 -0.9067847 0.3509834 -1.194863
#> iter3 -1.645167 0.7793540 -0.5383118 0.8288067 -0.9060949 0.3523418 -1.191467
#> iter4 -1.645304 0.7792514 -0.5383374 0.8287348 -0.9064084 0.3527767 -1.191322
#> iter5 -1.645309 0.7792690 -0.5383863 0.8287727 -0.9064384 0.3528409 -1.191334
#> iter6 -1.645308 0.7792716 -0.5383929 0.8287778 -0.9064403 0.3528486 -1.191336
#> 
#> $d.fn
#> [1] 3.00251e-07
#> 
#> $d.par
#> [1] 4.66612e-06
#> 
#> $iterations
#> [1] 6

    Fourth, Bootstrap is applied to evaluate the standard error and p-values of each coefficients estimated by ILSE. We observe four significant coefficients.

    s2 <- summary(ilse2, Nbt=20)
#> ===================Start bootstrapping================
#> [1] "==============running process: 10% ============="
#> [1] "==============running process: 20% ============="
#> [1] "==============running process: 30% ============="
#> [1] "==============running process: 40% ============="
#> [1] "==============running process: 50% ============="
#> [1] "==============running process: 60% ============="
#> [1] "==============running process: 70% ============="
#> [1] "==============running process: 80% ============="
#> [1] "==============running process: 90% ============="
#> [1] "==============running process: 100% ============="
#> ===================Finish bootstrapping================
s2
#>             Estimate std. Error   Z value     Pr(>|Z|)
#> intercept -1.6453080  0.1823854 -9.021049 0.000000e+00
#> X1         0.7792716  0.2303623  3.382809 7.174851e-04
#> X2        -0.5383929  0.1932418 -2.786110 5.334484e-03
#> X3         0.8287778  0.2571963  3.222355 1.271415e-03
#> X4        -0.9064403  0.2507468 -3.614962 3.003912e-04
#> X5         0.3528486  0.2002457  1.762078 7.805612e-02
#> X6        -1.1913363  0.1621764 -7.345927 2.042810e-13

    In ILSE package, we also provide Full Information Maximum Likelihood for Linear Regression fimlreg. We show how to use it to handle the above missing data.

    fimllm <- fimlreg(Y~Xmis)
#> Warning in nlm(lf, startvals, ...): NA/Inf replaced by maximum positive value
print(fimllm)
#> $beta
#>  intercept         X1         X2         X3         X4         X5         X6 
#> -1.9601651  1.0788227 -0.8895770  1.2461242 -1.4036280  0.9226424 -0.8530146 
#> 
#> $iterations
#> [1] 75
#> 
#> $stop.code
#> [1] 1

    We also use bootstrap to evaluate the standard error and p-values of each coefficients estimated by ILSE. We observe only one significant coefficients.

    s_fiml <- summary(fimllm, Nbt=20)
#> ===================Start bootstrapping================

    Visualization

    We visualize the p-vaules of each methods , where red line denotes 0.05 in y-axis and blue line 0.1 in y-axis.

    pMat <- cbind(CC=s_cc$coefficients[,4], ILSE=s2[,4], FIML=s_fiml[,4])
library(ggplot2)
df1 <- data.frame(Pval= as.vector(pMat[-1,]),
                    Method =factor(rep(c('CC', "ILSE", "FIML"),each=p)),
                    covariate= factor(rep(paste0("X", 1:p), times=3)))
ggplot(data=df1, aes(x=covariate, y=Pval, fill=Method)) + geom_bar(position = "dodge", stat="identity",width = 0.5) + geom_hline(yintercept = 0.05, color='red') + geom_hline(yintercept = 0.1, color='blue')
